nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction can improve machine learning performance for hyperspectral optical imaging soil moisture estimation

Dataset: 679 samples collected during a five-day field campaign in May 2017 on an undisturbed bare-soil sample; each sample contains soil moisture and 125 spectral bands from 450 nm to 950 nm with ~4 nm resolution
Preprocessing: spectral features standardized using StandardScaler and dataset split into train and test with test size 0.3 and fixed random state 42 for reproducibility

Dimensionality reduction: PCA applied to standardized spectral features; number of principal components chosen to retain more than 99 percent of total variance using covariance matrix, eigenvalue distribution, and scree plot
Prediction model: Random Forest regressor with 100 trees, random state 42, trained on PCA-transformed features and evaluated with coefficient of determination R2

Dataset composition table: spectral bands reported from 454 nm to 950 nm and auxiliary soil temperature column; soil moisture values range approximately 25 percent to 43 percent with center near 32 percent

Data inspection: correlation heatmap shows strong interband correlations and representative bands with high redundancy (example bands at 642 nm and 742 nm), indicating virtual dimensionality lower than nominal
Explained variance ratios for first four principal components: PC1 = 0.9889, PC2 = 0.0064, PC3 = 0.0023, PC4 = 0.0016; cumulative after PC2 = 0.9953 (>99 percent)
Result of PCA component selection: retaining only PC1 and PC2 preserves over 99 percent of dataset variance, validated by scree plot showing sharp eigenvalue drop after PC2

PCA projection visualization: projection onto PC1 and PC2 reveals clearer separation and clustering by soil moisture values compared to higher-dimensional space, while projections including PC3 show stronger overlap
Random Forest baseline result: model trained on PCA-transformed features achieved R2 = 0.947, explaining approximately 94.7 percent of variance in soil moisture
Claim: Compressing 125 spectral bands into two principal components reduces redundancy and data complexity while preserving key predictive information relevant to soil moisture
Claim: PCA-based reduction supports computational efficiency and improved interpretability in hyperspectral machine learning workflows

Conclusion: PCA is an effective baseline dimensionality reduction strategy for hyperspectral optical imaging that can produce efficient feature representations and strong predictive capability for soil moisture estimation

Limitations and future work: study uses a single dataset from one campaign and one target variable; authors recommend evaluating alternative feature extraction methods and testing across diverse imaging scenarios and sensors
